questions.text: Which biological molecule is most immunogenic? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A (Proteins).

 

Explanation:

 

Proteins are the most immunogenic biological molecules. Their high immunogenicity stems from their complex chemical structure and diversity of amino acid compositions, which provide numerous epitopes for immune recognition. Proteins are composed of about 20 different amino acid types, offering greater structural diversity compared to other biological molecules. This complexity and diversity make proteins highly recognizable by the immune system, leading to robust immune responses.

 

Immunogenicity referes to the ability of a substance (antigen) to provoke an immune response in the body — that is, to stimulate the production of antibodies or activate T-cells. Proteins are known to be the most immunogenic biological molecules.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Polysaccharides - While polysaccharides are antigenic, they are less immunogenic than proteins due to their simpler structure with fewer types of monosaccharide units. They generally elicit weaker immune responses.
  • Option C. Lipids - Lipids are poorly immunogenic by themselves. They typically need to be conjugated with carrier proteins to enhance their immunogenicity and stimulate an effective immune response.
  • Option D. Nucleic acids - Like lipids, nucleic acids have low immunogenicity. They also require protein conjugation to enhance their antigenicity and become effective immunogens.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Proteins possess the highest immunogenicity among biological molecules due to their complex structure, diverse amino acid composition, and ability to present multiple epitopes to the immune system.

questions.text: Which item below does not qualify as personal protective equipment? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Lab coat

 

A lab coat is not a personal protective equipment.

 

While lab coats are worn in laboratory settings to protect clothing and skin from spills and splashes, they are not classified as PPE. PPE refers to more specialized equipment designed to provide a barrier against specific hazards.

 

Other 3 options are considered as PPE

 

Educational Objective:

 

Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) are:

 

  • Gloves - protect hands.
  • Gowns/ aprons - protect skin and clothing.
  • Masks protect the mouth/nose and respirators protect the respiratory tract from airborne infectious agents.
  • Goggles - protect eyes.
  • Face shields - protect face, mouth, nose, and eyes.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman is evaluated for primary infertility. Hysterosalpingography was done and reveals the finding shown below. What is the anomaly seen in the image? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Septate uterus

 

Explanation:

 

  • The anomaly seen in the given hysterosalpingogram is suggestive of a septate uterus.
  • A septate uterus is characterized by the presence of a septum in the endometrial cavity which hasn’t disappeared after fusion of the 2 Mullerian ducts
  • On HSG, a septate and bicornuate uterus are commonly mis-diagnosed
  • If the angle between the 2 horns is <75, it is likely a septate uterus (As in this question)
  • If the angle between the 2 horns is >105, then it is likely a bicornuate uterus
  • However, an HSG is not the ideal ix of choice
  • An MRI is the best Ix for Mullerian anomalies

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Uterine didelphys: Uterine didelphys appears as 2 completely separate uterine cavities on the HSG with no communication whatsoever

 

 

Option C. Bicornuate uterus: Bicornuate uterus: This appears as 2 horns of the uterus which are widely separated (angle > 105 degree)

 

 

Option D. Unicornuate uterus: Unicornuate uterus: Single horn on the HSG

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anomaly seen in the image is a septate uterus which is characterized by the presence of a septum in the endometrial cavity which hasn’t disappeared after fusion of the 2 Mullerian ducts.

 

Ref: Page 47, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gyn 6th edition

questions.text: A gymnasium owner found that people drank ice tea while exercising in his gym. He further mentioned that the subsequent weight loss was solely due to ice tea. This is a type of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Spurious association

 

A spurious association occurs when a relationship between two variables is falsely inferred, often due to the presence of a confounding variable. In this case, the gym owner observed that people drank ice tea while exercising and then experienced weight loss. However, the weight loss is actually due to the exercise, not the ice tea.

 

The gym owner incorrectly attributed the weight loss solely to the consumption of ice tea, which is a classic example of a spurious association—where the real cause (exercise) is overlooked or ignored, and an unrelated factor (ice tea) is wrongly identified as the cause.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct association: This would imply a straightforward cause-and-effect relationship; such as exercise leading directly to weight loss. This is not applicable here because the claim was that ice tea, not exercise, caused the weight loss.

 

Option B. Indirect association: An indirect association occurs when the relationship between two variables is mediated by one or more additional variables. For example, exercise might lead to increased metabolism, which in turn leads to weight loss. This is not applicable in this scenario because the weight loss is directly due to exercise, not mediated by another factor like ice tea.

 

Option D. No association: This would imply that there is no relationship at all between the variables. However, in this scenario, the gym owner has incorrectly claimed an association, which makes it a spurious association rather than no association.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A spurious association occurs when a relationship is wrongly inferred between two variables due to a confounding factor. In this case, the gym owner incorrectly attributed weight loss to ice tea consumption rather than the true cause, which is exercise.

questions.text: The diagnosis of a carcinoid tumor is done by urinary estimation of? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 5 HIAA

 

Explanation:

 

Carcinoid tumors are neuroendocrine tumors that secrete serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine). When metabolized, serotonin produces 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA), which is excreted in the urine. Neuroendocrine tumors like carcinoid are causes of secretory diarrhea, and specific diagnostic markers include elevated serum Chromogranin A (CgA) and urinary 5-HIAA.

 

 Other Options:

 

Option A. VMA (Vanillylmandelic Acid): VMA is a metabolite of catecholamines (epinephrine and norepinephrine). It is elevated in pheochromocytoma and neuroblastoma, not in carcinoid tumors.

 

Option B. Metanephrines: These are also metabolites of catecholamines and are elevated in pheochromocytoma. They are not associated with carcinoid tumors.

 

Option C. Catecholamines: These are hormones including epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dopamine. They are elevated in conditions like pheochromocytoma and neuroblastoma, not in carcinoid tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carcinoid tumors are neuroendocrine tumors that secrete serotonin, which when metabolized produces 5-HIAA that can be measured in urine as a diagnostic marker. Chromogranin A (CgA) is another important tumor marker for carcinoid tumors.

questions.text: Glucose load for screening diabetes in pregnancy is:  (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 75 gm

 

Explanation:

 

According to the majority of guidelines, including the WHO, IADPSG (International Association of Diabetes and Pregnancy Study Groups), and DIPSI (Diabetes in Pregnancy Study Group India) guidelines, a 75 gm glucose load is used for screening diabetes in pregnancy.

 

Note - The ACOG (American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists) guidelines follow a two-step process where the first step involves a 50 gm glucose load for screening, and if positive, a 100 gm glucose load for confirmation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 25 gm: Not used in any standard screening protocol.

 

Option B. 50 gm: Used in the initial step of the ACOG two-step screening process, but not the most common single-step screening load.

 

Option D. 100 gm: Used in the second step of the ACOG two-step screening process, not for initial screening.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For screening diabetes in pregnancy, the 75 gm glucose load is widely used according to various international guidelines, including WHO and IADPSG.

questions.text: Which of the following does NOT indicate a state of prediabetes? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. All of the above.

 

Explanation:

 

None of the options listed (A, B, or C) actually indicate prediabetes. Instead, they represent values below the diagnostic thresholds for diabetes. Prediabetes is specifically defined as:

Fasting plasma glucose (FPG) = 5.6-6.9 mmol/L (100-125 mg/dL), termed "impaired fasting glucose" (IFG)

Plasma glucose levels between 7.8 and 11.0 mmol/L (140-199 mg/dL) following oral glucose challenge, termed "impaired glucose tolerance" (IGT)

HbA1c of 5.7-6.4%

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fasting glucose levels below 126 mg/dl: This is not a specific indicator of prediabetes. While prediabetes (100-125 mg/dL) falls within this range, so does normal glucose (<100 mg/dL). FPG ≥126 mg/dL is the diagnostic threshold for diabetes.

 

Option B. 2-hour post-glucose (PG) levels below 200 mg/dl: This includes both normal (<140 mg/dL) and prediabetic (140-199 mg/dL) ranges. A 2-hour PG ≥200 mg/dL indicates diabetes.

 

Option C. Glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) levels below 7%: This includes normal (<5.7%), prediabetic (5.7-6.4%), and even some diabetic (6.5-6.9%) values. HbA1c ≥6.5% is diagnostic for diabetes.

 

Option D. All of the above: Correct answer as none of these values specifically indicate prediabetes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prediabetes has specific diagnostic ranges (FPG 100-125 mg/dL, 2-hour PG 140-199 mg/dL, or HbA1c 5.7-6.4%) that represent intermediate hyperglycemia between normal glucose tolerance and diabetes.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 38-year-old female who is experiencing substantial hair loss for 4 months and has a history of COVID-19 infection 8 months ago? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Telogen effluvium

 

  • The pattern of hair loss in this clinical scenario is telogen effluvium.
  • The condition described is characterized by the sudden onset of scalp hair loss, typically occurring one to two months after a triggering event, which may include high fever, infections (such as Cholera, Typhoid, or COVID-19), surgery, trauma, starvation, myocardial infarction (MI), pregnancy, or hemorrhage.
  • This type of hair loss is associated with an increase in the shedding of telogen club hairs due to the premature termination of the anagen proliferative phase of the hair cycle following a period of significant stress.
  • When telogen hair shedding lasts for more than six months, it is termed “chronic diffuse telogen hair loss.” The main causes of chronic diffuse telogen hair loss include thyroid conditions (both hyper- and hypothyroidism), severe iron deficiency anemia, acrodermatitis enteropathica, and malnutrition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Androgenetic alopecia: Typically presents as a patterned hair loss and is more gradual. It is driven by genetic factors and hormonal influences and does not usually have a sudden onset associated with illness.

 

Option C. Alopecia areata:

  • An autoimmune condition where the body's immune system attacks hair follicles.
  • It results in small, round, and smooth patches of hair loss, which can coalesce but often do not cause complete hair loss.

 

 

  • It's not directly linked to illnesses like COVID-19 and does not typically present as diffuse hair loss across the entire scalp as suggested in the question.

 

Option D. Trichotillomania:

  • A psychological condition where individuals compulsively pull out their own hair, leading to hair loss.
  • Hair loss pattern tends to be irregular with varied length hairs, and examination often reveals broken hairs.

 

 

 

  • The history provided does not suggest any compulsive behavior or the typical patchy, irregular pattern seen with trichotillomania.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Telogen effluvium is a form of non-scarring hair loss characterized by the diffuse shedding of hair resulting from the early entry of hair into the telogen phase (the resting phase of the hair cycle). This condition is often triggered by significant physiological stress, severe illness, or major life events.

 

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 89 page no 32.24, 32.39, 32.40, 86.17, 89.6, 89.14, 89.17, 89.20 89.24, 89.25, 89.46

Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9th edition page 1509

Harrisons principles of internal medicine 21st edition 387

questions.text: Which of the following is the mechanism of action of thiazides in DCT? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Blockade of Na-Cl Symporter

 

Thiazide diuretics act by blocking the sodium-chloride symporter in the distal convoluted tubule of the kidney. This action leads to decreased reabsorption of sodium and chloride, resulting in increased excretion of these ions along with water, thereby producing a diuretic effect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blockade of Na-K-2Cl Symporter: This is the mechanism of action of loop diuretics like furosemide, not thiazides. Loop diuretics inhibit the sodium-potassium-2 chloride symporter in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle.

 

Option C. Blockade of Aldosterone Receptors: This describes the mechanism of action of spironolactone and eplerenone, which are aldosterone antagonists. They work in the collecting ducts of the kidneys.

 

Option D. Blockade of Epithelial Sodium Channels: This is the mechanism of action of potassium-sparing diuretics like amiloride and triamterene, which act on the collecting ducts of the kidneys.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thiazide diuretics primarily work by inhibiting the sodium-chloride symporter in the distal convoluted tubule of the kidney. This inhibition reduces sodium reabsorption, leading to increased excretion of sodium and water, thereby lowering blood pressure and reducing edema.

questions.text: What is the recommended time gap between the application of two live vaccines? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 4 weeks

 

  • According to the guidelines of the World Health Organization (WHO), there should be a minimum interval of 4 weeks (28 days) between the administration of two live vaccines.
  • This is to ensure that the immune system has enough time to respond to each vaccine and generate an adequate immune response without interference from the other vaccine.
  • Two live vaccines otherwise can be given together on the same day

 

Educational Objective:

 

General rules for multiple vaccine administration: –

 

  • 2 live vaccines can be given together
  • Live and killed vaccines can be given together
  • Cholera vaccine and Yellow fever vaccine cannot be given together
  • OPV is a live vaccine where single dose is not sufficient for immunization
  • 2 live vaccines can be administered simultaneously at different sites (or at an interval of 4 weeks)

questions.text: A woman on anti-depressants presents with bleeding. She gives a history of bulky stools which sticks to the pan. Which of the following vitamin deficiency can cause bleeding in this condition?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vitamin K

 

Option D. Vitamin K: Vitamin K is essential for blood clotting, and its deficiency can lead to a bleeding tendency. Bulky stools that stick to the pan can be indicative of malabsorption issues, which could result in inadequate absorption of fat-soluble vitamins, including Vitamin K. This deficiency can lead to bleeding problems.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Vitamin A deficiency is not typically associated with bleeding disorders but can lead to other health issues, including vision problems.

 

Option B. Vitamin D: Vitamin D deficiency can result in various symptoms, but it is not known to directly cause bleeding disorders.

 

Option C. Vitamin E: Vitamin E deficiency may lead to neurological and muscle problems but is not a common cause of bleeding disorders.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bulky, greasy stools that stick to the pan (often described as "steatorrhea") can be indicative of malabsorption, a condition where the absorption of nutrients, including fat-soluble vitamins, is impaired. Vitamin K is a fat-soluble vitamin crucial for the synthesis of blood clotting factors in the liver. Deficiency of vitamin K can lead to impaired blood clotting and a tendency to bleed.

 

Vitamin K is a fat-soluble vitamin crucial for the synthesis of blood clotting factors in the liver. Deficiency of vitamin K can lead to impaired blood clotting and a tendency to bleed.Top of Form

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 532

questions.text: What is the vector for Orientia tsutsugamushi? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mite

 

Orientia tsutsugamushi is the causative agent of scrub typhus, a disease endemic to the Asia-Pacific region. The vector for this pathogen is the larval stage of trombiculid mites, commonly known as chiggers. These mites transmit the bacteria to humans through their bite, typically occurring in areas with heavy vegetation and grassy fields where these mites are commonly found.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Louse: Lice are vectors for other diseases such as epidemic typhus (caused by Rickettsia prowazekii) but not for scrub typhus.

 

Option C. Tick:  Ticks are vectors for diseases such as Lyme disease, Rocky Mountain spotted fever, and tularemia but not for scrub typhus.

 

Option D. Flea - Fleas are vectors for diseases such as plague (caused by Yersinia pestis) and murine typhus (caused by Rickettsia typhi) but not for scrub typhus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The vector for Orientia tsutsugamushi, the causative agent of scrub typhus, is the mite, specifically the larval stage known as chiggers.

questions.text: A mother brought her 14-year-old mentally retarded child with complaints of joint pain and an irresistible urge to bite his fingers and lips. On investigation, his serum uric acid level was found to be elevated. The child is likely suffering from which disorder? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lesch-Nyhan syndrome


Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is a genetic disorder caused by a complete deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT). This enzyme plays a critical role in the purine salvage pathway, where it helps recycle hypoxanthine and guanine back into nucleotides rather than allowing them to degrade into uric acid. In the absence of HGPRT, there is an excessive accumulation of uric acid, leading to symptoms such as joint pain, gout, and hyperuricemia. The classic symptoms of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome include severe neurological dysfunction, self-mutilating behaviors like biting fingers and lips, and elevated uric acid levels, which perfectly match the clinical scenario described in the question.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Xanthine oxidase deficiency: Xanthine oxidase is an enzyme involved in purine metabolism, specifically converting xanthine into uric acid. A deficiency would lead to low uric acid levels, not elevated levels as seen in this patient. Symptoms of self-mutilation and neurological issues are not associated with xanthine oxidase deficiency.

 

Option B. Thymidylate synthetase deficiency: Thymidylate synthetase is an enzyme involved in pyrimidine metabolism, not purine metabolism, and it does not affect uric acid levels. Deficiency would result in impaired DNA synthesis but not the symptoms seen here, such as self-mutilation and elevated uric acid.

 

Option D.  CPSII defect: CPSII (carbamoyl phosphate synthetase II) is an enzyme involved in pyrimidine synthesis. Its deficiency leads to disorders related to pyrimidine metabolism but does not cause hyperuricemia, joint pain, or self-mutilation as observed in Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:


Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is characterized by severe neurological dysfunction, self-mutilating behavior, and elevated uric acid levels due to the complete deficiency of the enzyme HGPRT.

questions.text: Which of these options is not a means of directly transmitting communicable diseases? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Droplet nuclei

 

  • Airborne transmission by droplet nuclei is a method of indirect transmission of diseases.
  • Droplet nuclei are tiny particles of size 1-5 microns range that may be formed by either due to evaporation of droplets coughed or sneezed into the air or are formed from aerosols.
  • These droplet nuclei remain airborne for long periods of time and can transmit diseases like tuberculosis, influenza, chickenpox, measles, Q fever and other respiratory infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Direct Transmission Methods:

 

Option A. Vertical transmission: This occurs when infections are passed from mother to child during pregnancy, childbirth, or breastfeeding. Examples include HIV and congenital syphilis.

 

Option B. Contact with soil (B): Direct contact with contaminated soil can lead to infections. Soil-transmitted helminths and diseases like tetanus are examples.

 

Option D. Droplet transmission: This involves large respiratory droplets (typically greater than 5 microns) that are expelled when an infected person coughs, sneezes, or talks. These droplets can travel short distances and infect individuals through mucosal surfaces (e.g., eyes, nose, mouth). Examples include the common cold, influenza, and COVID-19.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Droplet nuclei represent an indirect transmission method, as they can remain airborne for long periods and travel over distances, whereas vertical transmission, contact with soil, and droplet transmission are forms of direct transmission of communicable diseases.

questions.text: Identify the contraceptive shown in the given image: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Female condom

 

Explanation:

 

  • The image is of a female condom. 
  • It is made of aa synthetic nitrile sheath with one flexible polyurethane ring at each end
  • One ring is open – lies outside the vagina.
  • The closed ring is fitted under the symphysis like a diaphragm
  • Male condoms should not be used simultaneously due to friction leading to slippage of condom or tearing
  • Also offers protection against STDs

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Male Condom:

 

 

Option C. Cervical diaphragm:

 

 

Option D. Cervical Cap:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The female condom is a synthetic nitrile sheath with one flexible polyurethane ring at each end, providing contraceptive protection and protection against STDs.

 

Ref: Page n 612, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text: In evaluating a patient with nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR), which of the following findings would be atypical for a classification of 'very severe’? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neovascularization of disc

 

  • In evaluating a patient with nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR), it is important to understand the typical and atypical findings associated with the disease severity:

 

This is considered an atypical finding for NPDR and is generally associated with proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR). NVD indicates a more severe and advanced stage where new blood vessels grow on the optic disc.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Venous Bleeding: In NPDR, more common findings are microaneurysms or dot hemorrhages.

 

Option C. Retinal Hemorrhages: Common in NPDR, especially as the severity increases. These hemorrhages are often small and scattered throughout the retina.

 

Option D. Microaneurysm: A hallmark and typically one of the earliest signs of NPDR. These are small, round, red spots seen on fundoscopic examination caused by capillary dilatation.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

When examining a patient with diabetic retinopathy, finding neovascularization would necessitate reclassification to proliferative diabetic retinopathy, which requires different management strategies including possible laser therapy or anti-VEGF injections to prevent further vision loss.

choices.text: Trinucleotide mutation in FMR-1 gene
Mental retardation
Large everted ears

questions.text: All of the following are features of fragile X syndrome except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Micro-orchidism

 

Macro-orchidism (large testicles) are seen in fragile X syndrome, not micro-orchidism.

 

Fragile X syndrome is caused by a trinucleotide repeat expansion in the FMR1 gene on the X chromosome. This expansion leads to a deficiency in the FMRP protein, which is important for neural development and function. Males with fragile X syndrome often have macro-orchidism, which can be observed during childhood and becomes more apparent during puberty. Other physical features of fragile X syndrome may include a long and narrow face, prominent forehead and chin, and large ears that are often everted. Intellectual disability and behavioral problems are also common features of the syndrome.

 

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Collect water from already leaking taps
Before collecting, let water flow for at least 1 minute
Water sample container is kept close to the tap avoid spillage
Collect from a gentle stream of water to avoid splashing

questions.text: How is water collected for bacteriological examination during a disease outbreak? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Collect from a gentle stream of water to avoid splashing

 

When collecting water for bacteriological examination, especially during a disease outbreak, it is crucial to follow proper procedures to avoid contamination and ensure the sample's accuracy. The best practice is to collect water from a gentle stream to avoid splashing, which can introduce contaminants from the environment into the sample.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Collect water from already leaking tape: Not recommended as it could contaminate the sample and may lead to false results.

 

Option B. Before collecting, let water flow for at least 1 minute: Before collecting, let water flow for at least 2 minutes

 

Option C. Water sample container is kept close to the tap to avoid spillage: It is a good practice but this practice alone does not ensure the proper collection of the sample.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When collecting water for bacteriological examination during a disease outbreak, it is crucial to collect from a gentle stream of water to avoid splashing and potential contamination. This practice ensures the accuracy and reliability of the water sample.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient reports a gradual increase in breathlessness over the past few months. On physical examination, a prominent left parasternal heave is noted, along with hepatomegaly. Auscultation reveals a loud systolic murmur. What is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pulmonary arterial hypertension

 

Explanation:

 

The key findings strongly suggest pulmonary hypertension (PAH):

 

  • Gradual onset of dyspnea
  • Left parasternal heave (right ventricular hypertrophy)
  • Hepatomegaly (right heart failure)
  • Loud systolic murmur (functional tricuspid regurgitation)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulmonary regurgitation: Produces an early diastolic murmur, not systolic

 

Option B. Pulmonary embolism: Usually acute onset, not gradual progression

 

Option C. Pulmonic stenosis: Produces an ejection systolic murmur, but lacks right heart failure features

 

Educational Objective:

 

A triad of chronic dyspnea, left parasternal heave, and hepatomegaly is highly suggestive of pulmonary arterial hypertension.

questions.text: Which nerve passes through the foramen marked in the image below? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Inferior alveolar nerve

 

The marked structure is the mandibular foramen, which is an opening located just below the mandibular angle.

 

  • The inferior alveolar nerve (IAN) is a branch of the mandibular nerve (CN V3).
  • The IAN descends behind the lateral pterygoid muscle, passing between the sphenomandibular ligament and the mandibular ramus, and enters the mandibular canal via the mandibular foramen.
  • The mandibular foramen is the entry point for the IAN and the vessels of the mandible.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lingual nerve:

 

  • It is a branch of the mandibular nerve (V3), which is the third division of the trigeminal nerve.
  • The lingual nerve provides general sensory innervation (touch, pain, temperature) to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
  • It is closely associated with the chorda tympani nerve (a branch of the facial nerve) which carries taste fibers from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. However, the lingual nerve itself doesn't carry taste sensation; it just provides a pathway for the chorda tympani nerve.

 

Option B. Mandibular nerve:

 

  • The mandibular nerve is the third division (V3) of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V), which is the main sensory nerve of the face.
  • It has both sensory and motor components.
  • The sensory branches of the mandibular nerve include the buccal, lingual, and inferior alveolar nerves, which innervate areas such as the lower teeth, gingiva, skin of the cheek, and anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
  • Its motor fibers innervate the muscles of mastication (chewing) and other muscles like the mylohyoid, anterior belly of the digastric, tensor tympani, and tensor veli palatini.

 

Option C. Chorda tympani nerve:

 

  • It's a branch of the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) and carries taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
  • It also carries preganglionic parasympathetic fibers to the submandibular and sublingual salivary glands, which play a role in salivation.
  • While it is not a branch of the mandibular nerve, it is closely associated with the lingual nerve (a branch of V3) in the oral cavity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inferior alveolar nerve is another major branch of the mandibular nerve (V3) which provides sensory innervation to the lower teeth (mandibular teeth) and the surrounding gingiva. Before it enters the mandibular canal in the jaw, it gives off a branch called the mental nerve, which exits the jaw through the mental foramen to supply sensation to the lower lip and chin. The inferior alveolar nerve also carries motor fibers to the mylohyoid muscle and the anterior belly of the digastric muscle.

questions.text: An 80-year-old woman presents with a progressive decline in daily activity. She gives a history of staring into space with frequent visual hallucinations. Pathology reveals Lewy bodies in neurons. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Parkinson’s Disease

 

The presence of Lewy bodies, which are aggregates of alpha-synuclein protein, in neurons suggests either Parkinson's disease or Lewy body dementia. Given the patient's symptoms of progressive decline in daily activity, visual hallucinations, and pathology findings, Parkinson's disease is the most likely diagnosis.

 

  • Lewy Bodies: These are characteristic of Parkinson’s disease and Lewy body dementia. They are intraneuronal inclusions primarily composed of alpha-synuclein.
  • Visual Hallucinations: These are more common in Parkinson's disease and Lewy body dementia compared to other neurodegenerative disorders.
  • Parkinson’s Disease: The diagnosis is supported by the clinical history of visual hallucinations and progressive decline, alongside the pathological finding of Lewy bodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Prion’s Disease: Typically presents with rapidly progressing dementia and myoclonus. EEG shows characteristic periodic sharp wave complexes, and CSF may show elevated 14.3.3 protein. This does not match the patient's clinical picture.

 

Option C. Huntington’s Disease: An inherited condition characterized by the classic triad of dementia, chorea, and psychiatric manifestations. This condition usually presents earlier in life and has a strong family history component.

 

Option D. Alzheimer’s Disease: Primarily presents with memory loss and later with visual-spatial problems and the "four A’s" (amnesia, agnosia, apraxia, aphasia). Pathologically, it is characterized by beta-amyloid plaques and tau protein tangles, not Lewy bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Lewy bodies in neurons and clinical features such as visual hallucinations and progressive decline in activity are indicative of Parkinson’s disease.

questions.text: Keratin in the skin is softer than keratin in the nails because keratin in the skin has: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fewer disulfide bonds

 

Explanation:

 

The hardness and strength of keratin structures directly correlates with the number of disulfide (S~S) bonds present. Keratin is rich in cysteine residues, which can form disulfide bonds between their sulfhydryl (-SH) groups. These covalent crosslinks significantly increase the structural rigidity of keratin. Nail keratin contains a higher density of disulfide bonds than skin keratin, making nails harder and more rigid. The fewer disulfide bonds in skin keratin allow for greater flexibility and softness, which is functionally appropriate for skin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fewer salt bridges: While salt bridges (ionic bonds between oppositely charged amino acid side chains) do contribute to protein stability, they are not the primary determinant of keratin hardness. The difference in hardness between skin and nail keratin is specifically related to disulfide bond content.

 

Option C. Higher sodium content: Sodium content is not a determinant of keratin hardness. Keratin's structural properties are determined by its amino acid composition and the covalent and non-covalent interactions between protein chains, not by sodium ion content.

 

Option D. Different water affinity: Although different keratins may have varying levels of hydration, the primary factor determining hardness is the degree of crosslinking via disulfide bonds. Water affinity may affect some properties but is not the main reason for the hardness difference between skin and nail keratin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hardness gradient observed in different keratin-containing structures (skin, hair, nails) is primarily determined by the density of disulfide crosslinks between cysteine residues, with harder structures like nails containing significantly more disulfide bonds than softer structures like skin.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of chronic alcohol use is admitted to the hospital. He presents with anxiety, tremors, and agitation after his last drink 24 hours ago. Which of the following medications is most appropriate for control of alcohol withdrawal symptoms? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lorazepam

 

 

Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine, a class of medications that act as central nervous system depressants, similar to alcohol. In cases of alcohol withdrawal, benzodiazepines are the first-line treatment because they help alleviate symptoms by enhancing GABAergic activity, which is reduced during alcohol withdrawal. This helps to stabilize the central nervous system, reducing anxiety, tremors, and agitation.

 

Among benzodiazepines, lorazepam is preferred, especially in patients with liver disease, because it does not undergo hepatic metabolism to active metabolites, making it safer in individuals with compromised liver function.

 

Other benzodiazepines such as chlordiazepoxide or diazepam may also be used, but lorazepam is often chosen in clinical scenarios where hepatic function is a concern.

 

Other sympatholytic drugs to manage withdrawal symptoms  – Beta blockers; Clonidine and Lofexidine

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fomepizole: This is an alcohol dehydrogenase inhibitor used primarily in the treatment of methanol or ethylene glycol poisoning. It is not indicated for the treatment of alcohol withdrawal symptoms.

 

Option C. Disulfiram: Disulfiram is used as a deterrent in alcohol dependence by causing an unpleasant reaction when alcohol is consumed. However, it is not used to manage withdrawal symptoms and is contraindicated in acute alcohol withdrawal.

 

Option D. Buspirone: Buspirone is an anxiolytic that is used to treat generalized anxiety disorder. It is not effective in managing alcohol withdrawal symptoms and does not have the CNS depressant properties needed to alleviate withdrawal symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:         

 

Lorazepam is the most appropriate medication for managing alcohol withdrawal symptoms due to its CNS depressant effects and safety profile, particularly in patients with liver impairment.

questions.text: The term Couvelaire uterus is associated with: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Uteroplacental Apoplexy

 

Couvelaire uterus, also known as uteroplacental apoplexy, results from bleeding into the myometrium in cases of placental abruption. This occurs when blood from the retroplacental hematoma extravasates into the myometrium, causing the uterine musculature to be infiltrated with blood. The myometrium appears purple-blue with ecchymotic patches. This pathology is associated with severe forms of abruptio placentae.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Placenta Previa: Placenta previa refers to the abnormal implantation of the placenta in the lower uterine segment, partially or completely covering the internal cervical os. It is characterized by painless vaginal bleeding, not myometrial infiltration with blood. There is no connection between placenta previa and Couvelaire uterus.

 

Option C. Pregnancy-Induced Hypertension: While hypertensive disorders of pregnancy can increase the risk of placental abruption (which may lead to Couvelaire uterus), PIH itself is a distinct condition characterized by elevated blood pressure developing after 20 weeks of gestation. PIH is not directly associated with the hemorrhagic infiltration of the myometrium.

 

Option D. Postpartum Hemorrhage: Postpartum hemorrhage refers to excessive bleeding after childbirth, typically defined as blood loss exceeding 500 mL after vaginal delivery or 1000 mL after cesarean delivery. It is a complication occurring after delivery, whereas Couvelaire uterus develops during pregnancy as a complication of placental abruption.

 

Educational Objective:

Couvelaire uterus represents myometrial infiltration with blood following retroplacental hemorrhage in abruptio placentae, clinically recognized as uteroplacental apoplexy with characteristic purple-blue discoloration of the uterus

choices.text: Ubiquitination of proteins
Protein modification
Protein folding
Protein cleavage

questions.text: What do chaperones assist in?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Protein folding

 

Option C. Protein folding

 

  • True. Chaperones play a crucial role in assisting proteins in achieving their correct three-dimensional folded structure. They help prevent misfolding, aggregation, or denaturation of proteins, ensuring their functional conformation.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Ubiquitination of proteins

 

  • False. Chaperones do not assist in ubiquitination of proteins. Ubiquitination is a process by which a small protein called ubiquitin is added to target proteins to mark them for degradation. Chaperones have a different role in protein biology.

 

Option B. Protein modification

 

  • Partially true. Chaperones are primarily involved in protein folding rather than direct protein modification. However, proper protein folding is essential for their biological function, and chaperones help ensure proteins achieve their correct three-dimensional structure during or after synthesis.

 

Option D. Protein cleavage

 

  • False. Chaperones are not involved in protein cleavage. Protein cleavage typically refers to the enzymatic process of cutting proteins into smaller fragments, which is different from the role of chaperones in facilitating proper folding.

 

Educational objective:

 

Chaperones help to produce the correct spatial arrangement. Chaperones attach to nascent polypeptide chains and prevent wrong folding; so that folding is allowed only in the correct direction. They help in the assembly of tertiary and quaternary structure of proteins.

 

Examples of chaperones are a large family of proteins called heat shock proteins (HSPs). Any stress to the cell including heat, toxins, heavy metals, free radicals, radiation, bacteria, etc. will cause increased production of HSPs, and hence they are more correctly termed as stress proteins.

 

Improper protein folding may lead to prion diseases.
